title: tom-gordon-yes-movement-needs-new-prospectus-plan-b
story: Amidst mass fatalities and economic ruin, it turns out that what Scotland really needs is yet another crack at formulating a lsquoPlan Brsquo to Indyref.Therersquos tone deaf, and therersquos this.Little wonder that when she was asked about it on Newsnight on Wednesday, the First Minister seemed almost allergic to the issue.ldquoFor me, everything other than coronavirus right now is on hold. Irsquom going to continue to focus on coronavirus for as long as I need to. That is my total focus right now, she said.And understandably so.This weekrsquos independence debate was prompted by a Panelbase poll for the Scot Goes Pop website.It askedthe SNP and Greens should ldquoconsider including an outright promise of independence in their manestos for a future election, to give people an opportunity to vote for or against the ideaBoris Johnson blocked a referendum.The answers came back  per cent Yes, % No and % Donrsquot Know.:Latest poll predicts SNP set for huge win at  Scottish electionsCue the SNPrsquos leading advocates of a Plan B on independence, Inverclyde Councillor Chris McEleny and MP Angus Brendan MacNeil, demanding their idea be put on the SNP conference agenda.In the absence of Westminster granting Holyrood the power to hold Indyref, or a court saying Holyrood already has it, the manesto for the  Holyrood election ldquoshall state that the election of a pro-independence majority of seats shall be a mandate from the people of Scotland to commence independence negotiations with the UK Government.This idea of making an election victory the basis for independence, rather than a referendum that never comes, was backed by % of those who voted SNP at last yearrsquos election.As always, Mr McEleny and Mr MacNeil have a point. If the UK government wonrsquot grant a referendum, the SNP needs to think creatively. But they do not have a case.Apart from the usual objections - other countries wonrsquot recognise anything short of a referendum, and the UK canrsquot be forced to open negotiations - there is also the small matter of the world around us.The UK economy shrank by % in March and April - three times the fall felt in the entire   Crash.As Andrew Wilson, author of the SNPrsquos Growth Commission, said yesterday, we have ldquolost two decades of improvement and growth and that is desperate for living standards.Mr Wilson also warned Scotland faces a bleaker recession than the rest of the UK because of its highly exposed tourism and hospitality sector and longer lockdown.His comment that in Scotland ldquomany businesses have remained closed for longer than necessary at potentially fatal cost to both employer and employees generated awkward headlines for Ms Sturgeon.But there was also another, subtler line tucked away in his analysis.Rebuilding the economy will ldquorequire partisanship to be shelved in the national interest, he said.As the constitutional debate brings out partisanship like little , the implication is clear.The next Holyrood election will be the strangest yet. The SNPrsquos record, which the Tories hoped to denounce, has become a black hole thanks to Covid, while a crippled budget means manesto give-aways are a no-no.What will dominate is trust."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Nicola Sturgeon: Extend Treasury support to save jobs and prevent virus spread","description": "Nicola Sturgeon: Extend Treasury support to save jobs and prevent virus spread","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media UHCmDxy poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests UHCmDxy.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Right now, Ms Sturgeon is riding high on that metric, thanks in large part to her setting aside politics as usual, including on independence, to focus on the Covid crisis.She has dropped the snark and played the benign administrator.Mr Johnson, conversely, is losing trust as he seems to focus too little on the crisis while pursuing Brexit pell-mell asnothing had changed.If, having formally rejected an extension to Brexit trade talks yesterday, the PM finally takes the UK out of the EUrsquos embrace in January on hairshirt WTO terms, the Scottish Tories will become an even more distrusted brand and Jackson Carlaw yesterdayrsquos leader.That Panelbase poll suggested the SNP is already cruising to victory in , and quite possibly to another majority.:Scottish Labour reiterates opposition to second independence referendumIt doesnrsquot need a new independence position to win - or win bigger.Voters know where the party stands. A manesto commitment to a referendum when the coronavirus crisis allows will cover it.Adopting a fruitless Plan B strategy wonrsquot win more votes, but it could lose them by eroding trust.To demand it now is precisely the kind of blinkered self-indulgence that makes many people look askance at the Yes movement. Jumpy impatience is never becoming, especially when combined with hazy nostrums about what comes afterwards.For there can be noto Plan A, far less an advance to a Plan B, without trying to answer the huge economic and social problems being generated at speed by the pandemic.That hellish hard work may lack the quick gratication of a process wheeze, but it has to be done before electors will consider whether independence is the next best step.What the SNPrsquos excitables need first and foremost is a Prospectus B to make the case when the time is right.But that, like our rubble economy, will take years to rebuild.

title: proud-family-business-j-charles-making-splash-fresh-fish-delivery-service
story: Aberdeen-based J Charles, which has a retail unit in the city as well as processing facilities for the commercial market, took the ldquoagonising decision to stay open and build up their fledgling online delivery serviceExpressFreshFishThe business was started  years ago by Wilfred Charles, carried on by his son John on hisfrom tea-planting in India, and is now run by his son Andrew who has led the company through many decades of dficult challenges.ldquoAndrew has always had a passion for the industry as well as working in it, but the onset of Covid has caused a lot of anxiety and what we have had to go through to continue has been fairly horric, said his we Shirley, who also works in the business.Rather than furlough or make redundant their  staff, the family decided to remain open and build up ExpressFreshFish which had been set up several years previously but not properly launched.When the lockdown began, Andrew and Shirleyrsquos -year-old son Henri, who had been training in the business, took it over and developed it.The fledgling business is now a success, delivering fresh fish all over the country, but it has been  weeks of hard work for the staff and family, including daughter Libby. She had been training in Perthshire as an eventer when the pandemic hit but ed to help, packing fish and making deliveries, after first attending to her horse early each morning.Said Shirley: ldquoHenri was learning the business buying fish at Peterhead market every day but is now factory based in Aberdeen since Covid and although we had a website set up for ExpressFreshFish - ExpressFreshFish -we had no carriers and no process set up in the factory.ldquoIn the beginning we were just getting one or two orders every couple of days but we kept working at it because it was a focus.However, after making the decision to keep going, the fishing boats tied up but Andrew continued to drive to Peterhead at am every morning to seeanything had been landed.Once the boats stopped going out, the businessrsquos regular transport companies, who would normally take the fish from Peterhead to Aberdeen, decided to furlough their staff which meant even more problems for J Charles.ldquoIt really has been tough but we have just all had to work together, said Shirley. ldquoNormally I would just work in the office a couple of days a week but now Irsquom packing fish in the factory and making deliveries.Fortunately the boats started going out again and the transport companies restarted after a three week break.Due to concerns about quality, the family made deliveries themselves with Henri at one point making a three hour round trip to Ballater to deliver two haddock to an elderly customer.At the same time standards had to be maintained in the factory, while increasing hygiene measures and maintaining social distancing.ldquoThe staff have been brilliant, said Andrew. ldquoIn spite of alarming publicity all our staff, led by office manager Sarah and factory manager Jim, continued to work through this dark time with little time off. The importance of food workers was not supported at the start of Covid which made it dficult for factories like ours to remain open.Although it has had a slow start, the online service has given the family and staff a focus and now orders are coming in from as far away as the south of England including, perhaps surprisingly, other fishing towns like Portsmouth.Repeat orders from satisfied customers are common, with many buying in bulk in order to freeze supplies.Popular items are haddock, both smoked and fresh, cod, lemon sole and scallops and, as there is currently no continental market for Scottish produce, high end items like lobsters and langoustines have been added to the lines.Sustainability as well as freshness is a priority for the company.ldquoOne of the most important aspects of supplying quality Scottish fish to our customers is knowing the product comes from well-managed, sustainable fisheries, said Henri.ldquoJ Charles promotes all Scottish caught fish species as being sustainable and all customers who eat Scottish fish can do so with confidence it is coming from a rich abundant healthy fishery.ldquoOur aim is to make available to our customers top quality fresh Scottish sustainable fish landed by our Scottish fishermen.Supporting local charities is a key feature of J Charles and, as well as donating % of any online orders marked CWT to medical charity Camphill Wellbeing Trust, there is % off purchases from NHS and care workers.ExpressFreshFish also has a Facebook page which carries fish recipes and tips on how to best cook their products.

title: kevin-mckenna-black-lives-really-matter-need-go-beyond-knocking-old-statues
story: Thus, the sight of Black Lives Matter protesters toppling the statue of an old slave trader in Bristol and threatening to remove Henry Dundas, who played a key role in delaying the abolition of the slave trade for  years in , from his perch high above Edinburgh city centre and others of his ilk elicits a suite of predictable responses. The most representative of these was from Neil Oliver, the television history-man who said: ldquoI find it very concerning that this kind of behaviour is a step on the road that leads to mob rule, to the guillotine.Mr Oliver, of course, has form when it comes to adding a purple hue to his vivid declamations. During the  Scottish independence referendum he described the Yes campaign as ldquoa hate-fest. He thinks that the mere prospect of a second referendum is ldquoa cancerous presence. The Electoral Reform Society begged to dfer on how the referendum campaign was conducted, describing it as providing a gold standard in the quality of political engagement.Not long after this Mr Oliver became President of the National Trust for Scotland. This organisation has several artefacts of questionable provenance but you have to become a member before you can access its properties, so these should be okay hellip for the time being anyway.:Black Lives Matters protesters plan to topple Glasgow statue of a former PM - but have wrong man"@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Black Lives Matter organisers urge protesters to stay calm","description": "Black Lives Matter organisers urge protesters to stay calm","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media CGNrTD poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests CGNrTD.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Irsquove no great enthusiasm for disassembling statues, but it hardly sets us on the road to perdition. This is merely a rather more visceral rendition of what governments and universities do routinely when they remove degrees and honours from figures who fall from grace. Viewed purely from an artistic perspective many of these old statues are of limited aesthetic value anyway and Irsquod be inclined to remove most of them on those grounds and replace them with something more vivid and edgy that honours the nobility of lesser realms. Stick the old slave-owners in a museum and let their mass defenestration be regarded as a moment in history of itself.What is more important here, I think is this historic opportunity of pulling down the much more insidious and less visible structures which permit racism and racial discrimination to flourish in the long term. I was moved by Anas Sarwarrsquos speech on Thursday at Holyrood in which he starkly outlined our casual indference to racial inequality in civic Scotland.Purely in the political realm I have been disobliging of Mr Sarwarrsquos machinations and stratagems in seeking to shape the Labour Party in Scotland. But there was no doubting his passion on this occasion as he took us through the myriad executive positions in Scotland by which civic influence is wielded and told us they were the exclusive preserve of whites. Scotland and Glasgow in particular is home to a prominent, well-educated Asian community who have contributed greatly to the economy and culture of our nation ndash Mr Sarwar himself is a gted son of this group.Yet, in  smart, erse and inclusive Scotland doesnrsquot trust any of them to be major decision-makers in the civic boardroom cliques which determine future strategies in education, health and the arts. Therersquos little point in posting pictures on Facebook of your presence at a Black Lives Matter demonstration and the harrowing of the nationrsquos rogue statuaryyoursquore not shamed and embarrassed by such civic and cultural apartheid.In September,  Glasgow University published a report of how it had benefited directly from the Atlantic and Caribbean slave trade. The figure of poundm emerged but it admitted that this was probably incomplete, so sinewy and deep-rooted were the routes and means of profiteering from slavery. Itrsquos inconceivable that other Scottish academic institutions, venerable trades houses, finance firms and family fortunes have not similarly benefited from the routine torture, rape and murder of millions of black people.Nor was this confined to the actions of a few old merchants whose stone effigies are currently looking a bit precarious. In a book of essays published in  called Recovering Scotlandrsquos Slavery Past, Professor Sir Tom Devine and a group of his fellow academics outlined the extent to which almost the entire economy of Scotland in the th and th centuries was under-written by profits from the Caribbean slave markets.:Black Lives Matter: Every Scottish street linked to slave-trade revealedIn his concluding essay, Sir Tom wrote: ldquoThe funds which helped to lubricate the Chesapeake trade were drawn from Scottish landowners, trustees, tradesmen, physicians, military officers, spinsters, widows and university professors, among many others. That also meant the profits of the slave-trade tobacco business were widely distributed through these financial networks well beyond the ranks of the active merchant community itself.Perhaps itrsquos reasonable to question how far back we need to go and whether the raking of ancient ashes can achieve anything. Yet, no-one is proposing punitive land and property-grabs or to impoverish those whose present fortunes are directly descended from racist genocide. Itrsquos surely also reasonable to encourage these families, firms and trades bodies to make a similar audit of their slavery-derived fortunes. Like Glasgow University they could make proportionate reparation with endowments and scholarships for the descendants of those whose suffering once fed and watered the entire Scottish nation.When the Labour Party began to introduce all-women, constituency short-lists they were criticised for endorsing the sort of discrimination they purported to revile. Yet, such a response failed to acknowledge that centuries of male privilege saw many men being promoted and honoured merely by their membership of exclusively all-male golf clubs and masonic lodges. A similar programme of positive discrimination in favour of our Black, Asian and minority ethnic communities is clearly requiredScotland seeks to become a truly inclusive and erse nation.Andblack lives really matter then our response has to be much more profound and long-lasting than knocking down a few old statues.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald

title: ba-treatment-workers-a-national-disgrace
story: In a report published today by the Westminster Transport committee, politicians have lashed out at the national carrierrsquos actions towards its employees.The airline initially said staff would be put on furlough as its fleet was grounded, but weeks later announced , employees were to be made redundant.It then emerged there were plans for , staff to be reemployed with poorer conditions, which is currently under consultation.The Transport Select Committeersquos report not only criticised the airline, but also said Home Secretary Priti Patelrsquos decision to introduce a blanket  day quarantine for people coming in to the country had to eb scrapped at the end of the month.The MPs argue it should be replaced with a ldquomore flexible and risk-based approach.The committee has also recommended that the Government pick up the pace on a recovery strategy for the aviation industry by scrapping air passenger duty for six months and mirror the Scottish Governmentrsquos move to give airlines and airports  months business rates relief.Huw Merrimen MP, chairman of the Committee, said: ldquoThe impact of coronavirus may sadly mean that the loss of some jobs in the aviation sector is justied. The behaviour of British Airways and its parent company, IAG, is not. It falls well below the standards expected from any employer, especially in light of the scale of taxpayer subsidy, at this time of national crisis..He added: ldquoIt is imperative that the UK Government finds a way to get aviation back on its feet. We donrsquot believe this fits with a blanket  day quarantine period for travellers to the UK.A spokesman for BA said: Mr Merriman made clear several weeks ago that the Committeersquos report would be lsquofuelled by the kind and impassioned messagesrsquo he received, rather than the facts. The facts are clear. The Government has no plans to help the sector restart and recover as evidenced by the  day quarantine regulation.ldquoWe find ourselves in the deepest crisis ever faced by the airline industry.ldquoWe will do everything in our power to ensure that British Airways can survive and sustain the maximum number of jobs consistent with the new reality of a changed airline industry in a severely weakened global economy. ldquo

title: coronavirus-edinburgh-family-one-first-bring-covid-scotland
story: It comes after new genetic research revealed that the disease began circulating in Scotland during February and that it was brought here from continental Europe.Trish Lumsden, , tried to get her eight-year-old son, Christian, tested for the disease when he fell ill with a cough and fever on February , but was told by her GP that it was "probably a cold".By that time he had been back at school for nearly two weeks.UK-wide travel guidance on Italy was updated on February , by which time the country - which quickly became Europes Covid hotbed - had recorded hundreds of cases, a handful of deaths, and had quarantined  towns in Lombardy and Veneto.: Coronavirus spreading in Scotland in FebruaryAnyone who had arrived in the UK from northern Italy since February  was urged to self-isolatethey developed symptoms within  days, or to self-isolate as a precaution - regardless of symptoms -they had been in any of the areas by then under lockdown.Like hundreds of other Scottish holidaymakers who had travelled to Europe for the half-term break, the Lumsden family - who had been ski-ing in the Dolomites - ed to Scotland on February , making them exempt from this advice.But it is now thought the virus would have been widespread well before this date in Italyrsquos popular ski resorts and tourist centres such as Venice ndash which the Lumsdens visited hours before flying home."We didnt even realise until we go there that the Carnival was on and it was incredibly busy," said Mrs Lumsden."We couldnt even get into St Marks Square it was so busy. We didnt really think that much about it, but I do remember someone on the taxiboats - where youre really squashed in - coughing behind me."And I did think urgh, but I didnt think about it in relation to coronavirus."By the time Christian started getting a cough and a fever on the th they had opened the drive-thru test centre at the Western and because I was taking my eldest daughter to hockey on the Saturday and Christian was going to be going to his friends, I thought I could really be doing with getting him tested to make sure hes not going to infect other people."So I phoned the GP on Saturday morning and he said would you be worried about him normally,it wasnt for coronavirus . I said no, so he said  itll just be a cold then, dont worry about it - theyre only interestedyou came back from Italy since the th."He said since wed come back on the th there was nothing to worry about. At the time I thought that sounded a bit stupid, but now I think it sounds really stupid.": Number of patients in hospital cut % at start of outbreak"@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Coronavirus in numbers: UK death toll at ,","description": "Coronavirus in numbers: UK death toll at ,","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media gHqFBAP poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests gHqFBAP.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Mrs Lumsden, from Currie in Edinburgh,ed to work in the Royal Mile but both she and husband Tom soon developed "strange symptoms", including a hangover-like headache that lasted a week, fever, shivers, aching bones, and extreme fatigue that lasted for three weeks."The pair us of would be on the sofa and out for the count at pm," she said.Another of their four children, -year-old Stella, went on to develop a cough, and son Sebastian, , suffered a cough, fever and sore legs.All of the children were kept out of school after falling ill, but research now suggests that most people become infectious around three days before symptoms emerge.On January , Scotlands then chief medical officer Dr Catherine Calderwood said it was "highly likely" the countrys first Covid- case would be detected within days.In the end, the first known case was not identied until March  - in a patient in Tayside who had just ed from a ski trip to northern Italy.It is unclear exactly why the February  threshold was chosen, as Italy confirmed its first cluster of cases in Lombardy on the st and its first Covid deaths on the nd, suggesting - on the basis of the average incubation time and how long it usually takes to become seriously unwell - that the the virus had been circulating in the region for weeks.: Covids silent spreaders are the big question of the pandemicThe UK only escalated travel restrictions to ban "all but essential travel" to Italy on March , the day that Italy was plunged into a nationwide lockdown."The week after we came back was when it all kicked off, and everyone we knew was like oh, you were in Italy - you could be carrying it," said Mrs Lumsden."We could have been a spreader, I dont know."I would have loved to have had [Christian] tested and I cant really understand why he wasnt."At the time I did think it was strange, but you put your faith in the doctor and think they must know. But I really did question it."How many other people ing to Scotland from north Italy at this time called the NHS as they had symptoms and were told they were fine "Scientists have traced Scotlands Covid outbreak - which has now claimed  lives - to  unique versions of the virus imported from continental Europe.They are unsure exactly when it first arrived, but using genomic sequencing have been able to establish that community transmission was already underway in February - meaning that people with no history of travel to known Covid hotspots in Europe and Asia were becoming infected.However, interim CMO Dr Gregor Smith - who unveiled the findings last week - stressed that flu and other viral pathogens were also spreading in February.He said: "We wont be able to say with certaintysomeone who was experiencing the kinds of symptoms we would associate with Covid- - the cough, the fever - was specically associated with Covid-."A Scottish Government spokesman said: ldquoThe approach taken to advising ing travellers from specic countries and areas in mid-February was agreed by the four UK Chief Medical Officerson the best and most up to date expert scientic and medical advice at the time of making the decision.

title: scotland-gets-set-welcome-tourists
story: The Scottish Government has given the tourism and hospitality sectors a provisional reopening date of July , assuming the fight to suppress Covid- continues to be successful.But amid warnings the two-metre social-distancing rule will lead to pubs, restaurants and museums being restricted in their ability to claw back much-needed cash, Highlands and Islands businesses have stated that ferry restrictions are ldquosimply catastrophic for trade.The North Coast  route, which provides up to pound million to the Highlands economy a year, is expecting even more Scots to enjoy its sites and spend money in local businesses this summer.Tom Campbell, executive chairman of NC, said: ldquoWith international tourism shredded and the thoughts of many turning to post-lockdown travel, there is every likelihood more Scots than ever before may well follow the lead of tens of thousands of visitors who have already explored the -mile route.:Coronavirus: Edinburgh family fear they brought Covid to Scotland after sons symptoms dismissed as just a cold after Italian ski tripldquoSeismic change in how Scots and other UK nations holiday as a result of Covid- could result in a staycation boom, helping to ensure the success of the NC, businesses and communities along the route continues through dficult times.ldquoWersquore expecting to see more UK visitors heading to Scotland and driving and cycling will be the way people will want to take their holidays.With more people expected to travel by car this summer amid social distancing and capacity concerns around public transport, car parks and public toilets are set to be reopened ndash with hand hygiene playing a leading role in the continued fight against coronavirus.Forestry and Land Scotland operates dozens of visitor centres and car parks across the Highlands.Chief executive Simon Hodgson, said: ldquoWe are grateful that many people have exercised their patience throughout lockdown and we will be looking to carry out the necessary maintenance and safety checks on our car parks and other leisure and recreation facilities that will allow us to gradually reopen them.ldquoWe anticipate that we will have some car parks and mountain bike trails open by the end of phase two and will be working towards opening our visitor centres as soon as it is practicable and safe to do so in phase three.A spokesperson for Highland Council said the authority is working towards reopening as many toilets and car parks as possible.But the anticipated staycation boom is unlikely to be felt in Scotlandrsquos island communities after CalMac Ferries warned that with current social-distancing measures continuing, only % of normal passenger numbers will be able to travel.Rob McKinnon, chief executive of Outer Hebrides Tourism, said: ldquoMany tourism businesses on the islands which have seen no revenue since October  are on a knersquos edge and will be unable to survive until April  without some trading season this year, or further Government support, which has not yet been proposed.:Scotland set to enter lockdown Phase  NEXT WEEK - what changes for youldquoWersquod welcome a boost or a bounce, as opposed to a surge or an invasion, in autumn, when people who have been unable to come earlier in the year decide to visit in October or November which would really help our businesses, when social distance happens naturally, and you do have the space to feed your soul. Wersquoll need a bit of patience and understanding as we get back into gear and adjust to social distancing, restock some supplies, and deal with everyonersquos nervousness as we adapt to the new normal.ldquoWe are lucky that many of our visitors are regulars and we can rely on them to do their part.Gordon Morrison, chief executive ofthe Association of Scottish Visitor Attractions, has indicated that many outdoor attractions could reopen as soon as next weekend,Nicola Sturgeon confirms stage two of the Scottish Governmentrsquos roadmap to easing the lockdown later this week ndash but warned that ldquomany are weighing up whether it will be viable to open on July .He added: ldquoRegardless of when attractions choose to reopen, there will be a signicantly reduced number of visitors to our sites this year and there is absolutely no doubt that a longer-term support package for the sector will definitely be needed to ensure the survival of many of our members.Pubs and restaurants are eager to welcome customers again, with those with outdoor spaces set to be able to reopen in phase two of the exit strategy.Emma McClarkin, chief executive of the Scottish Beer  Pub Association, said: ldquoIt is important consumers feel safe and comfortable when they are finally allowed to enjoy a beer in a pub again, with operators across Scotland busy over the coming weeks getting their premises ready for opening in the new normal.ldquoThere are still issues needing addressed ahead of reopening for the pub sector though, with the majority of premises unable to viably operate at a two-metre social distance.

title: orkneys-stunning-heritage-star-new-film
story: Now, the ancient remains and Orkneyrsquos other intriguing monuments are to provide a magical backdrop to an animated feature film which could launch the story of the islands onto the international stage. Itrsquos hoped that Lugi ndash The Brodgar Boy could eventually become a major cinema release, helping to spotlight Orkney and, indeed, Scotlandrsquos often overlooked Neolithic history, echoing the impact of Pixarrsquos  animation Brave, and boosting tourism across the islands. The feature- film will tell the story of a disabled boy who must unite his peoplethey are to defeat evil forces, and is expected to take viewers on an animated tour of the Orkney Islandsrsquo most precious heritage sites. The idea originated from Orcadian illustrator and cartoonist Alex Leonard who has been developing the film with Belfast-based animation company ALT Animation. It recently beat competition from almost  filmmakers in  countries to secure major development funding from Creative Europe. ALT Animation has also received support from Northern Ireland Screen. Intended as a family-friendly movie, the story will use the boy herorsquos adventures to explore some of the mysteries surrounding Orkneyrsquos most ancient monuments, such as the famous settlement of Skara Brae and the Ring Of Brodgar. The sites predate Stonehenge and the Pyramids of Egypt, prompting suggestions that the islands were the epicentre of human existence , years ago. Although strictly fiction, it will be woven around real archaeological evidence and understanding gleaned during excavation of the sites. Some early illustrations have been based on Structure Ten at the Ness, thought to be one of the largest stone-built Neolithic structures in Britain and built around BC.Measuring ft by ft, archaeologists believe it was abandoned around BC, when hundreds of cattle were slaughtered and consumed during a huge feast. Leonard, who lives in Sandwick, was inspired to create the character and dramatic backdrop to the story after visiting the Ness of Brodgar settlement in  and being astounded by its size and history. ldquoI couldnrsquot really grasp fully the scale of what they are finding in terms of the number of buildings and the size of them. I was captivated and couldnrsquot understand why more people didnrsquot know about it, he said. ldquoI kept wondering what it looked like when Ness was in its prime. I went home and started to draw and sketch ideas. ldquoIt was a labour of love that at first I thought could make a little kidsrsquo book.The idea attracted the attention of Tim Bryans, writer and producer from Belfast-based ALT Animation, which has now secured interest from a number of award-winning studios around Europe keen to work collectively on the project.Leonard said the focus is now oncreating a screenplay and a trailer that showcases the story, and looking for a partner to take the film to full production. ldquoWe would love to think that it would eventually go on general release, added Leonard. ldquoWe donrsquot know who will come on board and donrsquot know yetit will be computer generation, D, an arthouse project or have much wider appeal. We are just happy for it to have found its feet.ldquoOur inspiration is Pixarrsquos Brave which did so well for tourism in Scotland.Brave, which told the story of an adventurous princess and featured the voice of Billy Connolly and Kelly Macdonald, was a global hit and resulted in tourism agency VisitScotland spending pound million on the joint marketing campaign with Disney. The associated television campaign was said to have reached around  million people in the UK, North America and Europe, while written material reached  million people worldwide.The film was estimated to have generated more than poundm in business for Scotland over  years.

title: sir-tom-devine-scotlands-role-slavery-must-acknowledged
story: Devine says that attacking statues of public figures connected to the th and th-century slave trade ldquoachieves little and fails to acknowledge the real truth of historic Scottish involvement in the slave systems.ldquoTargeting statues is a largely meaningless gesture which might make some people feel good about themselves for a little while, he says. ldquoThis though, does little to address the very real and ongoing issue of racial prejudice in Scotland and throughout the UK.Devine spoke out at the end of a week in which attention in Scotland has been focused on the imposing statue of Henry Dundas in Edinburghrsquos St Andrew Square which dominates the city centre.Dundas, one of the most powerful figures in Scotland in the early-th century, used his influence to delay the abolition of the Atlantic slave trade by  years. Edinburgh City Council is to consider a plan to rededicate the statue to those who continued to suffer enslavement during this period.Across the world other statues have been targeted in the wake of international protests about the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis two weeks ago. In Bristol last Sunday, a statue of the th-century slave trader, Edward Colston, was felled by protesters and flung into the harbour.Devine insisted that focusing merely on statues and other artefacts from the past was misplaced. ldquoIf people want to talk about Scottish involvement in slavery they need to be aware of the full picture. In the th and early-th centuries the Scottish nation as a whole was lsquocomplicitrsquo in slavery. The markets and financial s from lsquothe nefarious businessrsquo helped to lay the foundation for modern Scotland and shaped the economy from which we now benefit.In , Devine edited a collection of essays about Scotlandrsquos historic involvement in the slave plantations. Recovering Scotlandrsquos Slavery Past demonstrated how all levels of Scottish society, from the early-th century to the end of slavery in the British Empire, were directly or indirectly affected.:Without slavery Glasgow wouldnt exist: The brutal truth about Scotlands slaving pastldquoThe new research showed that merely concentrating on prominent mercantile figures fails to take account of the fact that Scottish society as a whole benefited from chattel slavery: weavers of lsquoslave clothrsquo for the West Indies fishermen who exported dried fish to feed the slaves workers in the mills who processed the raw cotton harvested by slave labour the crews of the vessels who sailed across the Atlantic and the officials, lawyers and clergymen who administered the slave colonies and the spiritual needs of their owners.ldquoOnly by acknowledging the full extent of this nationrsquos role in slavery can we begin to construct a meaningful programme of response today to that dark period of history.lsquorsquoI am convinced that the evidence we now have suggests Scottish modernisation was even more dependent on the slavery factor than England. This was not because of involvement in the slave trade itself. Ships from Scottish ports rarely took part in that horrible commerce in human beings after . Rather it was based on the overwhelming place of tobacco, sugar and then cotton in Scottish external trade. The remarkable boom in these commodities depended entirely on armies of black slave labourers.In , Glasgow University published a report, based on more than two years of research, that revealed it benefited directly from the slave trade in Africa and the Caribbean in the th and th centuries. Its audit put the figure at pound million in todayrsquos money. Following this the university launched a wide-ranging ldquoreparative justice programme to include the creation of a centre for the study of slavery and to establish ties with the University of the West Indies.The study also raised questions about how the wealth of Glasgow and other parts of Scotland was accumulated. Devine praised the universityrsquos research and openness. ldquoThe research confirms that manmore Scots gained from the colonial trades based on slave labour than the tobacco lords and sugar princes who are now attracting such virulent media and political condemnation, he said.:Hundreds turn out lsquoto protectrsquo Glasgow war memorialldquoTherefore, it follows that today there must be institutions and families with links to those times and who prospered from the profits of chattel slavery. But so far, in Scotland, only the University of Glasgow has admitted how it benefited and how it intends to proceed by way of some form of recompense to the people of the West Indies. Why are others silent ldquoOne positive consequence of the current furore has been the triggering of a deeper awareness of the inequalities that black people in Britain and the US continue to encounter to this day and which have undeniable connections to slavery. ldquoYet in order to begin to heal that wound in Scotland, a soundly-based and open knowledge of the nationrsquos central part in slave history is an essential precondition.

title: jatin-haria-assume-infected-racism---vaccine-available
story: The Parliamentrsquos official position now includes the statement ldquothat there is a responsibility on us all to identy and dismantle barriers of structural racism that exist in our society and institutions.It might not seem it, but itrsquos a huge milestone for Scotland.Until recentlythe general line was that Scotland was exceptional, and ldquoitrsquos not all bad here.Wersquore really all Jock Tamsonrsquos bairns, we donrsquot have a class system, we only played a bit part in the Empire, we were ardent abolitionists, ordinary Scots didnrsquot see a single shilling of the money earned from the backsof enslaved Africans, we awarded Nelson Mandela the freedom of the city, we welcome immigrants.Exceptional, exceptional, exceptional.One or two of these points are indeed true. But you can be the exception to the rule and, in some cases, racist at the same time. David Hume, one of the most eminent philosophers in the Scottish Enlightenment and close friend of Adam Smith, thought ldquothere never was any civilised nation of any other complexion than white. Burns could believe A Manrsquos a Man for Arsquo That and still make plans to go to work as a slave driver in Jamaica. And never forget that it was Scottish emigrants who set up the Ku Klux Klan.Closer to home, the Scottish Government can state that ldquoScotland has a wonderfully erse society and we are all, each and every one of us, equal citizens and stakeholders of Scotland.At the same time, a charge of racial hate crime is levied against someone on average every three hours, every single day,  days every year. It comes as no surprise then that a third of all black minority ethnic people in Scotland report having experienced discrimination in the past two years.BME people are twice as likely to live in poverty as their white counterparts and, not coincidentally, inequality and discrimination persist in the labour market.Research shows someone with a non-British sounding name has to send nine times more applications in order to receive an interview. Public bodies try to get around this using ldquoname blind application processes, yet the Scottish Governmentrsquos own workforce data shows ethnic disparities of Ben Nevis proportions.Even more worrying was the data showing that between  and ,  murders with a known or suspected racist element were recorded, with many having littleany media interest.All too often these were seen as ldquoone-off incidents rather than any broader reflection on Scottish society. Yet during this period, these  cases gave Scotland a higher per-capita rate of murder associated with racism than England or Wales.In the last Social Attitudes Survey to look at discrimination, % of people in Scotland felt that there was sometimes a good reason to be prejudiced against certain groups.Thatrsquos more than one in every five of us. Itrsquos no wonder that more and more people are acknowledging that the ldquono problem here attitude needs to change into a beliefldquothat racism is a societal evil that we must all stand united against.A milestone has been reached ndash Scotlandrsquos parliamentary representatives are now standing up against racism. Itrsquos a small step forward. But standing up doesnrsquot move us any further forward.A key barrier to progress is peoplersquos assumption that they, personally, could never behave or think in a racist way. The truth is that anyone can. To solve this, perhaps we need to treat the pandemic of racism like we are being asked to treat Covid-.Assume you are infected. You may be asymptotic, but as Amy Cooper showed in Central Park, the symptoms can surface at any time. Follow the science and listen to those who know more than you about it. Keep the R number at  ndash donrsquot let racism spread.Andyour le is absolutely the same as it was before you acknowledged the racism ldquooutbreak, then you are doing something wrong.Luckily, a vaccine is already available ndash changing attitudes and behaviours. You can make changes for yourself, and help those around you to change. Learn more about social, structural and institutional racism believe people who say theyrsquore experiencing it educate people who want to downplay it.Donrsquot stand still, act. Letrsquos make the new normal an anti-racist one.Jatin Haria is executive director, Coalition for Racial Equality and Rights

title: north-sea-gave-liquid-gold-45-years-ago
story: The National Front marched in London, IRA bombs exploded, the Yorkshire Ripper was on the loose and coal miners celebrated a % pay rise watched, no doubt, by the new leader of the Conservative Party, Margaret Thatcher.And in the North Sea, an economic revolution was about to bubble up from the depths of the choppy waters.The feverish race to extract precious liquid gold from British waters had been played out since the sixties, as exploration companies used increasingly sophisticated technology to pinpoint oilfields which science suggested had to be somewhere.Finally, in mid-July  ndash exactly  years ago this week ndash the first of what would become countless billions of barrels of oil was brought ashore.A trickle at first, before long it would become a torrent wave after wave of luscious, thick, liquid gold that put the nation on its way to a more affluent future, launched Aberdeen as Europersquos oil capital, and sparked endless debates over whose oil it really was.Now, however, while a glut of North Sea oil languishes on ocean-going tankers following a collapse in demand and plunging prices, and the sector braces itself for its endgame, the heady days of  feel like a world away.And it may beg the question of what might have happenedall that oil hadnrsquot been found Pioneering and rival exploration companies had spent years trawling the North Sea for oil when, in September , BPrsquos semi-submersible rig Sea Quest drilled into what would become the Arbroath field and, a year later, the Forties field.In an interview given four decades later to mark the Fortiesrsquo anniversary, former Sea Quest driller Rob Lingard would tell how he ran to the messroom, grabbed a Colmanrsquos horseradish sauce bottle and snatched the first glug of black liquid gold to emerge from its depths.ldquoWhen I think back to that little, tiny rig we had up there compared to the size of them now, we did well, he recalled.ldquoWe were drilling away and the rig man said lsquoersquove got some oil on the shakersrsquo. We knew wersquod got into oil but we didnrsquot quite realise how big it was.But while BP had pinpointed the UKrsquos largest oilfield ndash quickly followed by Shellrsquos Brent ndash it would be Denver-based Hamilton Brothers, working on Argyll, km southeast of Aberdeen, that would win the race to bring oil ashore.Using a floating, semi-submersible drilling rig, the Transworld , modied to operate as a production , oil was pumped onto the ,-ton tanker Theogennitor.Within a week, on June , , the then energy minister Tony Benn was on board a hydrofoil at Tower Pier in London, heading down river to BPrsquos Isle of Grain refinery in the Medway Estuary to greet the tanker and its valuable cargo.ldquoI hold the future of Britain in my hand, he declared, clutching a bottle of the tankerrsquos crude oil aloft, adding that Britain was set to be one of the worldrsquos  great oil-producing nations.Before long, BP would be bringing its own oil ashore.In November , the Queen pressed a gold button to mark the opening of a pipeline at Cruden Bay which could whisk up to , barrels of BP oil on a -mile journey to the refinery at Grangemouth.Soon the black river was in full flow. By , Forties fieldrsquos four pound million BP rigs had produced . million tons of oil andhelped ensure Britain was no longer at the mercy of Opec oil prices.Within a decade, . million barrels of oil per day were being extracted from  North Sea fields across more than  installations.As more companies raced to take out leases to extract oil, terminals were built in Orkney and Shetland. Sullom Voe alone brought work for  people while Aberdeen shted attention from fishing to became Europersquos Klondike.Family businesses built on cod and herring switched to oil. The most successful, run by Sir Ian Wood, would become a multinational oil services company helping him towards an estimated net worth today of . billion.Aberdeen, meanwhile, boomed and losses felt by drting tourism and cod wars were offset by rich oilmen with very deep pockets.All of which couldnrsquot have come at a better time, as traditional industries across the UK collapsed, coal mines and shipyards closed, and car production ground to a halt.By the mid-s, the North Sea was providing % of the Treasuryrsquos revenues, enabling Conservative government tax cuts, covering the costs of unemployment, and paying off a historic balance of payments problem.And it provided a cushion for Margaret Thatcher to carry out sweeping industrial reforms while funding a consumer boom when, some argue, the income should instead have been invested in a Norwegian-style oil fund.While the SNP continued to declare it was Scotlandrsquos oil, the North Sea was, according to Tony Blair in , ldquoutterly essential to Mrs Thatcherrsquos electoral success.Few working offshore would have complained too much. Their  days on, five days off routine brought extremely good pay: the average salary within the oil and gas sector in  was pound, a year.But there was also constant danger. In the early days, workers were transported in helicopters without wearing harnesses, puffing on fags as they went. If weather grounded flights, some would be ferried from boats to rigs, clinging on to ropes high above crashing waves.Concerns that safety was not a high priority seemed validated in  by the Piper Alpha disaster which claimed the lives of  men and prompted improved health and safety measures. Helicopter crashes also brought tragedy to the sector.But still the black gold flowed. By the early s, the Forties field alone had delivered over two billion barrels of oil, while oil gushed from the North Sea at the equivalent of . million barrels every day, supporting , jobs across the UK.No-one can really know what would have happenedwe hadnrsquot found oil on our doorstep whether we would have been forced to innovate and find new, cleaner methods of providing energy earlier, embraced windfarms and electric vehicles sooner, or limped into economic catastrophe.However, itrsquos clear that a sector that is worth around poundbn to the economy, which supports around , jobs across the UK ndash % of them in Scotland ndash and has paid poundbn in production tax since the s, is changing.Ross Dornan, OGUKrsquos market intelligence manager, said: ldquoThe opening of the UKrsquos first oil pipeline serving the iconic Forties field was a major milestone in our industryrsquos history and a testament to the importance of North Sea oil to the UK economy which remains the case today.ldquoThe industry has gone on to make a hugely positive impact across the UK ndash producing more than  billion barrels of oil and gas, contributing hundreds of billions of pounds to the UK economy and supporting hundreds of thousands of high value jobs.ldquoToday, although the industry is facing some of its most dficult challenges, there is still signicant potential to be realised from the UK Continental Shelf.ldquoOur focus is on driving the recovery of our industry so we can make the most of future opportunities including our contribution to delivering energy security and playing a key role in the transition to a low carbon economy.

title: Opinion  Rosemary Goring  One Glasgow boy ran to tell the farmer    39 they coos are eating a    your grass  39
story: With falling temperatures, the village moved back indoors. Yoursquod scarcely know that there has been any lting of lockdown. One neighbour says her grandmother scoffs at the idea that the coronavirus crisis is like the last war, when she was a child in a nearby town. Although they were often hungry, they had complete freedom. Even when the air raid siren went, and they had to e into shelters, they did not feel the all-pervasive threat of today.Nor, unless they were extremely remote or unlucky, were people shut off from each other. We talk a lot about the power of modern technology to keep us connected, but in those times, whether you were in a village or a city, there was daily contact with other folk, evenyou lived alone. People wouldnrsquot have felt the need for video calls when they could nip out of theirdoor and visit whoever they liked nearby. The Blitz spirit is not entirely a myth, but the circumstances in which it thrived were very dferent from this pandemic.My mother lived in London and, in , like countless city children, was evacuated to the country. She was luckier than many, being sent not to strangers but to an aunt, who lived in Herefordshire, near the Welsh border. There was no running water, light was by paraffin lamp, her uncle was an irascible war veteran, and her aunt would often retreat to bed for days, finding the extra responsibility rather too much. But for an -year-old, collecting eggs from under hens, sauntering up the lane for still-warm jugs of milk from the farm, and seeing a night-time sky lit by stars was a revelation. From then on, she counted the days until she could leave London forever.Not all evacuees felt the same way. Encountering beetles and bugs for the first time was hard enough, but herds of cows with a bull among them must have been pretty alarming. One boy, who had never previously left the Gallowgate, ran to tell the farmer that ldquothey coos are eating arsquo your grass. Another Glaswegian, taken into a Perthshire home, escaped onto the roof when they ran him a bath. He thought they were trying to drown him.Recalling that period, my mother spoke of country folksrsquo shock at the poverty of inner city children, who had come from slums. Those who organised the mass evacuation were appalled to discover that, when asked to provide each child with a change of clothing, a toothbrush and enough food for a dayrsquos journey, a lot of families were unable to do so. It was a sobering eye-opener. Rural hardship was re, but it did not compare to the scale of urban deprivation: barefoot youngsters with rickets, scurvy, ringworm, or so underfed they were the colour of lard.Itrsquos hard to imagine what it must have felt like to be dropped into a world of fields and trees and pitch black nights, when you were used to well-lit canyons of concrete and stone or to find yourself alone in a bed, when usually therersquod be siblings on all sides, keeping you warm, and your parents only a step away. Some children were so miserable, they had to be sent home. For others, like my mother, it sparked a lelong love of the countryside.Not that she idealised her auntrsquos way of le. Some aspects of it were, for a Londoner, like stepping back in time. Nor, in the s, was there any glamorising of country le. It was often equated with backward attitudes and ignorance. If anything, most villagers dreamed of escaping to the city, or at least the suburbs, and a clean, warm house with all mod-cons.Irsquove been reading Dirk Bogardersquos memoir, Great Meadow, in which he recalls his childhood in the Sussex Downs, from the age of six. Between  and , he spent weekends and long spells of holiday in what his affluent parents called a cottage, but photos show as a substantial house. Later he was packed off to Glasgow, which he loathed, but thatrsquos another story. In Great Meadow, he and his little sister were looked after by a nanny, while his actress mother swanned around in a kimono, and his father raced up and down to London where he was on The Timesrsquos picture desk. Bogarde often mentions the healthiness of the country, compared to London, where public transport was frowned on, because of the risk of germs. This was a legacy, perhaps, of the Spanish flu.Bogarde loved everything about the cottage, but the most noteworthy feature was the outside lavatory. Every Friday he had to dig a hole in the garden and, under cover of dusk, empty the privy bucket into it. His great fear was of tripping, because sanitation was basic. Theyrsquod have a weekly bath, filled by their nanny, but his parents preferred going to the nearest pub for their ablutions.Years ago I visited friends in rural Perthshire who had an outside toilet. I rather liked it: it was made of wood, and smelled of sawdust. Unlike the shed at the bottom of many cottage gardens, one wall was open, so the view was lovely, even in the snow. You didnrsquot have to crunch over snails in the dark to reach it ndash bedrooms came with chamberpots ndash and as a guest there was no fear of ever being asked to empty it. To watch him on screen, yoursquod never think Bogarde was the man to cope with such a noisome task. If for any reason it suddenly becomes a necessary chore in our cottage, Irsquoll be with the Gallowgate evacuees, heading straight back to the flushing loos of the Merchant City.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald

title: brave-midges-summer---tourism-sector-needs-us
story: Maybe your minds eye is conjuring a picturesque lochside lodge or a glamping pod on the beach. The world may not currently be our oyster, yet Scotland hopefully soon will.News that the tourism sector could reopen for business ndash with a provisional date set for July  ndash has seen me gazing starry-eyed at holiday accommodation websites like a lovestruck teenage girl mooning over posters of Bros and A-has Morten Harket on her bedroom wall.After all these weeks in lockdown, venturing a handful of miles at most, the idea of soon being able to travel further afield is a prospect giddying and slightly terrying in equal measure.The notion of staying overnight in another set of four walls ndash be it booking a caravan at Wemyss Bay or a BB in Banchory ndash is so alien, it feels akin to being selected for a Mars mission.Over the past three months, le beyond my own little nook has often felt like an abstract concept. Cocooned in our sanitised bubbles, theres been moments I have viewed Jim Carreys character in The Truman Show as a kindred spirit.: Susan Swarbrick: When lockdown is over do I need to wear a bra Except in my instance the all-seeing eye of the camera facilitates endless rounds of Zoom calls and theres no hidden door you can step through to escape.Surprisingly, I havent gone completely stir-crazy. It has perhaps helped that Im a homebody at the best of times. While I wouldnt go as far as snooker player Ronnie OSullivan, who last week described lockdown as "the best three months" of his le, Ive not experienced prolonged cabin fever.Yet, ever since the announcement that the reopening of holiday infrastructure could be imminent, I suddenly have itchy feet. This coming Saturday I was due to head off for a week at a cottage near Stranraer, another lockdown landmark that has only served to stoke my wanderlust.Regular readers will recall some months ago that I lamented never having visited Dundee. My hankering to explore the city hasnt waned. Well, unless those who didnt take my musings in the good-natured way intended are waiting at the Tay Bridge with torches and pitchforks.I feel strongly about the need to get out and support Scottish tourism as soon as is safe to do so. I usually avoid July and August when the midges are at their most ferocious, but this year Ill grin and bear it, armed with a vat of Avon Skin So Soft and a stack of antihistamines.: Susan Swarbrick: Ive been to Georgia and Calornia. But Ive never been to Dundee ...Ditto when it comes to any grumblings about the weather. Invest in a decent set of waterproofs. Put on a jumper and warm socks. Place your trust in the restorative powers of a hearty bowl of Cullen skink. Now, go stick a pin in the map. Ill look forward to giving you a wave on the open roads.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald

title: ron-mckays-diary-worried-slavery-statues-nicola-sturgeon-start-renaming-bute-house
story: First they came for Basil Fawlty, next it will be Will Shakespeare. The BBC, in the craven way we are used to, has removed the funniest episode of Fawlty Rowers from its box set, the one where Basil, after a blow on the head, fails to get away with not mentioning the war. HBO has removed Gone With The Wind, not because itrsquos a bun fest of hackneyed plot and over-ripe acting, but because of the way it portrays black slaves. And donrsquot expect to see a blacked-up Olivier in Othello again. Anywhere.Where does it end  There have been hundreds of white actors ndash from Brando to just about any Hollywood star you could name ndash who have adopted a dferent ethnicity. Almost every cowboy movie made had whites cherry-blossomed to play "Indians". Are they all to be scrapped  And books  Are they to be banned or burned  Rudyard Kipling, Huckleberry Finn. And what about Gershwinrsquos Porgy and Bess  No more Summertime This is all frivolous and irrelevant compared to the real issue of confronting racism and attempting to make amends.I was only vaguely aware of Edward Colston until he rolled down the street in Bristol and plopped into the Avon ndash or at least his effigy did ndash and only then because a local rock band were boycotting the hall named after him.The hall is to be renamed but once itrsquos the Massive Attack Arena, is that it  Will the band happily play there and punters flock back, comfy in the place the slave traderrsquos money paid for but now rebadged These protests may be necessary, but are they sufficient  Isnrsquot there just the faint whf of hypocrisy over benefiting from the profits of murder and trafficking, as long as the shame isnrsquot named  Knock down Colston Hall  That may be the ultimate logic but it clearly isnrsquot going to happen. I doubt the names of the more than , slaves Colston traded were noted, or that their descendants can be traced. But reparations are due, not just airbrushing. Bristol owes.Not just Bristol. Liverpool, Edinburgh and particularly Glasgow, many of whose finer buildings were built on the enslavement of others. Irsquove written in the past and called for the renaming of the streets commemorating the traders like plantation owner Andrew Buchanan, after whom the street is named. So good on the anti-racism campaigners who did just that, pinning up alternative names.But it has to go further. There has to be restorative justice. Glasgow University, a place not renowned for radicalism, has committed to pay pound million in reparations to atone for its historical links to slavery, setting up a research centre with the University of the West Indies. The city needs to do more, rather than just say sorry.And Edinburgh  Nicola Sturgeon could start by renaming Bute House, which is steeped in the profits of slavery. Indeed, she could lead a campaign to pay for what we plundered.Taking down statues isnrsquot just window dressing, itrsquos a declaration that those we are meant to venerate, looking down from their perches, we despise and will no longer tolerate. Although I accept that agreeing criteria for removal is probably impossible.Therersquos a statue of Charlie Chaplin in Londonrsquos Leicester Square, or at least there was at the time of writing. Chaplin was a comic genius, but he bedded a succession of underage girls, including Lita Grey, at , whom he later hastily married in Mexico, probably to escape prosecution. Thatrsquos paedophilia. Should he end up in the Thames Pass me the SemtexOne monument which should be turned into aggregate is the Jim Crow stone at Hunters Quay in Dunoon. Itrsquos named after the segregation laws in the States, and may well have been coined by racist white American sailors when the Holy Loch was a US nuclear submarine base. The stone is repeatedly painted, cleaned and repainted with whatrsquos meant to look like a black face. Crivvens it looks more like a pregnant shark than a human. What is wrong with these people  Therersquos a petition out to remove it. Too woke. It needs attacked by a posse wielding jack hammers or atomised in some safe Semtex solution.Book inI HAVENrsquoT managed to learn Greek or play the cello in lockdown but I have done a lot of reading and too much TV. One utterly remarkable book, from someone Irsquom ashamed to say I had never heard of, but who deserves to be ranked as a giant in American literature, is A Dferent Drummer by William Melvin Kelley. Kelley, a black man, wrote the book in  when he was  and it couldnrsquot be more germane to why black lives matter.Itrsquos  in the deep South, a young black former throws salt on his field, shoots his horse and livestock, sets fire to his house and leaves the state. The entire African-American population, in their ones and tens, leave after him. What is stunning about the book, apart from the evocative prose, is that itrsquos all from the standpoint of the whites of the town, in their voices. Irsquom not sure anyone did that before. Kelley was not prolic, he died in , but this book stands as a monument no statue could ever do justice to.On the moneyI DONrsquoT knowyou can make bets on who will be awarded baubles in the honours list butyou can then my moneyrsquos on James Anderson, the man who has given pound. million to Scottish football clubs and who is promising more. He is a shoo-in for a serious honour like a knighthood. And his act of benevolence may also have the unintended consequence of saving his team, Hearts, from relegation, although I doubt it.Surgical strikeTuned into a TV drama called Hannibal which is about a husky-voiced Canadian detective who has a bipolar we and a sassy female partner . A woman is shot in the head in the woods, apparently left for dead, but wakes not knowing who she is and with a bullet lodged in the brain. She is taken to neurosurgery in Toronto where she is operated on ndash under anaesthetic one hopes ndash but conscious throughout, singing House Of The Rising Sun as they remove the slug from her heid. Sound ridiculous  Apparently not. Itrsquos called awake surgery and patients are given tasks to perform, like playing the guitar or violin, so they arenrsquot disturbing crucial brain s as doctors work. I donrsquot knowthis extends to pottery, but one woman in Rome made  Ascoli olives, the recipe for which is to stuff meat into the flesh of olives, coat in breadcrumbs and fry. If it had gone on longer perhaps shersquod have made a bolognese  They stopped her short of the coating and frying, to avoid making a mess and setting off the fire alarms.If she has to have follow-up surgery on her tumour theyrsquore going to ask her to prepare steak tartare and theyrsquoll do the op over lunch.

title: Opinion  Iain Macwhirter   Bagpuss Boris  followed the wrong science
story: The PM is losing supporters left and right. The Government is rudderless, drting making contradictory decisions or no decisions at all.Boris Johnson had nothing sensible to say about the Black Lives Matter demos which drove a coach and horses through the lockdown. He could either have endorsed the protests as legitimate on moral grounds, or called on the police to enforce the law. He did neither until forced to. Leadership was lacking.The belated introduction of a -day quarantine for travellers to Britain seems like a self-destructive exercise in closing the door after the viral horse has bolted. His Government is cancelling border checks on the , lorries that enter the UK every day, while also saying that the Brexit transition period will not be extended.:Nicola Sturgeon: Boris Johnson putting political interests ahead of the public interestJohnson is accused of allowing children in England to go to theme parks but not to schools, leading to further problems for students from disadvantaged backgrounds. The two-metre rule is causing massive problems as the economy tanks, yet the medical evidence for its effectiveness is contradictory.But the most serious accusation made last week against Boris Johnson was that he was asleep at the wheel in early March, and that his dilatory behaviour led to the deaths of tens of thousands of people.The claim was made by the former SAGE member, Professor Neil Ferguson .ldquoHad we introduced lockdown a week earlier, the Imperial College epidemiologist told MPs last week, ldquowersquod have reduced the final death toll by at least half.In other words,the UK Government had closed the schools and shops on March  instead of March , the official death toll might have been , instead of ,. This retrospectively validates Fergusonrsquos own forecast back in March that, on his model, lockdown should have kept the death toll to around ,.I think most now accept that the UK did just about everything wrong in its response to Covid-. We didnrsquot close the borders, didnrsquot protect care homes, abandoned testing and locked down too late. The question is: who is to blame for all this The editor of The Lancet, Richard Horton, in ldquoThe Covid Catastrophe which is to be published this week, names the guilty man: Boris Johnson. He failed to attend crucial meetings of COBRA, the Cabinet crisis committee, failed to listen to scientists, and thought the country should ldquotake it on the chin in order to protect the economy.But it was not just the PM who delayed lockdown by one week. This was also the policy of the Scottish Government.I happened to be in the Scottish parliament on March , the day that Leo Varadkar announced the closure of schools and universities in Ireland. At First Ministerrsquos Questions, Nicola Sturgeon explained why she was not following suit. She was, she insisted, ldquofollowing the science.School children sent home were likely to take the disease into their communities and to older people, ldquowhich might be a greater risk in terms of spread of infection than their being in school. She also said that parents would have to stay at home to look after them and this would denude staff for essential services like the NHS.:London Protests: More than  arrested as Boris Johnson condemns far-right protests as lsquoracist thuggeryrsquoIt all seemed sensible at the time. The national clinical director, Jason Leitch, was all over the media saying that the vast majority of us were going to get the virus anyway, because there was no vaccine, and that we had to ldquoprotect the vulnerable as it ldquoworked its way through the population.The release of SAGE minutes two weeks ago confirms that the scientic advisers were at best cool about lockdown. They may not have been in thrall to heartless herd immunity, but they did believe that trying to suppress the virus would be counterproductive.On March , the minutes say "SAGE was unanimous that measures seeking to completely suppress the spread of Covid- will cause a second peak.It added that it was ldquoa near certainty that countries such as China, where heavy suppression is under way, will experience a second peak once measures are relaxed.The scientic consensus was that eradication of the disease was not possible because it would spread until herd immunity ndash % of the population ndash finally burned the virus out. But Jacinda Ardern, the prime minister of New Zealand, took a dferent view. She closed the borders immediately cases appeared and kept them closed, and imposed a severe lockdown internally and suppressed the virus until it disappeared. Last week she declared victory over Covid ."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Coronavirus in numbers: UK death toll at ,","description": "Coronavirus in numbers: UK death toll at ,","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media gHqFBAP poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests gHqFBAP.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Only time will tell whether SAGE was right. There may indeed be a second wave and New Zealand will have very little immunity to it. Borders cannot be kept closed forever. However, the minutes seem to confirm that, as Professor Lawrence Freedman argued in the New Statesman, ldquothe Government was largely following SAGErsquos advice.Some have claimed that Nicola Sturgeon wanted to follow dferent advice and was overruled by Westminster. That isnrsquot the case. The First Minister was following the same scientic advice as Westminster, and made clear she did not believe lockdown was yet necessary or desirable on March .Itrsquos hard to believe that a weekrsquos delay could have led to , deaths, as many as on the first day of the Battle of the Somme. Scientists will debate this for years.Indeed, analysts in Bristol, led by the mathematical modeller Professor Simon Wood, now claim now that the disease peaked before lockdown was introduced, suggesting that SAGE was right.SAGE had always argued, as the minutes show, that the best way to contain the spread was hand washing, social distancing, and protecting the old and vulnerable. The UK Government was only persuaded of lockdown by Neil Fergusonrsquos infamous forecast, on March , that without it , would die.The one thing we have learned from coronavirus is that science is not a monolith and that scientists disagree as much as politicians. All of which makes little dference to the state of the PMrsquos popularity, which dropped dramatically during Cummingsgate and has not recovered.Tory commentators are whispering that Johnson has lost it, doesnrsquot look well. Has he fully recovered from Covid- himself  He nearly died, after all.Itrsquos dficult to tell with Boris Johnson because he never seems particularly in command. For an intelligent man, he is remarkably inarticulate. He ldquoums and ldquoahs his way through Prime Ministerrsquos Questions ashe is making it up as he goes along. The suspicion is that he is, and that he relied too much on Dominic Cummings to do the thinking for him.Before he became Prime Minister, Johnson had a reputation for being lazy and shallow. Three years ago, his Tory colleague and rival Michael Gove said that ldquoBoris cannot provide the leadership or build the team for the task ahead. Gove recanted ndash but it could be he was right all along.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald
